lcInstruction.p: The minimal DITA task topic is much like the minimal topic discussed in previous courses: a <task> root element (with an id attribute) that contains a <title> element.
Following the <title> element and an optional <shortdesc> element, use a <taskbody> element to contain the task content.
Within the <taskbody> the elements in a strict task conform to a very specific order. The elements in the <taskbody> are presented in this course in the order in which they occur.

step.cmd: Make a copy of the file task_sample_1.dita and open it in your editor.

info.note: If you are using a DITA-aware text editor, make sure you are in text mode, rather than Author or visual mode.

stepxmp.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE task PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Task//EN" "task.dtd"> <task id="my_first_task"> <title></title>
</task>

info.p: The first line (which begins with <?xml) is an XML declaration, which is a standard part of all XML files.

The second line is the DOCTYPE declaration, which tells DITA editors or DITA output generators that this is a DITA strict task topic. The programs then use that information when validating the content of the topic. The DOCTYPE will be different for each topic type that you create (including the general task).

step.cmd: Inside the <title> element, add the task title.

stepxmp.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE task PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Task//EN" "task.dtd"> <task id="my_first_task"> <title>Watching wild ducks</title>
</task>

step.info: The <taskbody> contains all the actual content in the task.

stepxmp.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE task PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Task//EN" "task.dtd"> <task id="my_first_task"> <title>Watching wild ducks</title> <taskbody>
</taskbody> </task>

step.info: This is the essential part of a DITA strict task topic. The two remaining steps in this unit add the first two child elements to the <taskbody> element.

step.cmd: Inside the <taskbody> element, add a <prereq> element.
step.info:
The <prereq> element lists prerequisites to perform the task. These prerequisites can include (but is not limited to):
Things the reader must have in hand
Information the reader must have
Previous tasks the reader must have accomplished

stepxmp.ph: (The next two examples only show the contents of the <taskbody> element; the other task elements are there, theyâ€™re just not shown, for clarity.)
stepxmp.pre: Before you go watching wild ducks, make sure you know what a wild duck looks like.

step.cmd: After the <prereq> element, add a <context> element.
step.info: The <context> element describes the purpose of the task. This can include background information or what the user will gain by performing the task. The <context> should be relatively brief; if you need to provide more detailed background information, consider creating a concept topic.

stepxmp.pre:
Before you go watching wild ducks, make sure you know what a wild duck looks like.

Watching wild ducks can be calming and recreational.

Read this to learn more about what you need to have a satisfying duck-watching experience.

step.info: At this point, the task has a title, a set of prerequisites, and a context. The next lesson covers how to add the actual steps to the task.
